fullProgramDescription: The Biological Engineering major is an interdisciplinary program that combines engineering principles with biological systems to develop innovative solutions to real-world problems. Students learn to apply engineering principles to understand and manipulate biological systems, from molecules to organisms. The program is designed to provide a strong foundation in mathematics, physics, and biology, as well as engineering principles and practices.
shortProgramDescription: The Biological Engineering major at MIT provides a comprehensive education in the application of engineering principles to biological systems, preparing students for careers in research, industry, or further study.
classHighlights: Foundational Courses: Students begin with foundational courses in mathematics (Calculus I–III), physics (Mechanics, Electricity & Magnetism), and biology (Introductory Biology, Biochemistry). These courses provide a necessary background for understanding biological systems and applying engineering principles.

Core Biological Engineering Courses: The core courses in Biological Engineering include Thermodynamics of Biological Systems, Transport Processes in Biological Systems, and Quantitative Physiology. These courses introduce students to the principles of biological engineering and provide a foundation for more advanced study.

Biological Engineering Depth: Students choose from a range of courses that provide depth in specific areas of biological engineering, such as synthetic biology, tissue engineering, and biomedical devices. These courses allow students to develop expertise in areas of interest and prepare for careers or further study.

Laboratory and Research Experience: Students gain hands-on experience in laboratory and research settings, applying engineering principles to biological systems and developing skills in experimental design, data analysis, and interpretation.

Engineering and Biology Electives: Students select from a range of elective courses that complement the core biological engineering curriculum, including courses in engineering, biology, and related fields. These electives allow students to explore areas of interest and broaden their knowledge.

Mathematics and Computational Methods: Throughout the curriculum, students develop skills in mathematical modeling and computational methods, applying these tools to understand and analyze biological systems.
learningOutcomes: Apply engineering principles to understand and manipulate biological systems.
Analyze complex biological systems using mathematical and computational models.
Design and conduct experiments to test hypotheses and validate models.
Communicate complex ideas and results effectively to technical and non-technical audiences.
Work effectively in teams to solve problems and develop innovative solutions.
Stay current with developments in biological engineering and related fields.
creditRequirements: 180–192 units (total), including General Institute Requirements and departmental requirements; semester credit system
additionalInformation: Students are expected to make satisfactory progress toward completing degree requirements. Research and internship opportunities are available, and students are encouraged to explore these opportunities to gain practical experience.
